title: Hello I am Leena!
text: A full time university student on a quest to master the art of Artificial Intelligence. When I’m not busy convincing my code to run without breaking, you can find me capturing the world through my camera lens—because if AI doesn’t take over, at least I’ll have some great photos to document it! My life is a fine balance between training neural networks and training myself to survive on minimal sleep. Join me on this adventure where the only thing more complex than AI algorithms is figuring out how to frame the perfect picture!

title: About Me
text: I completed my O’Levels in 2018 and went on to Singapore Polytechnic to pursue a Diploma in Bioengineering. After finishing my studies, I took a gap year and worked with Biosensors, a company specialised in building catheters as an Research and Design Engineer. I really enjoyed my entire time there where I get to witness the behind the scene of the building something for inert of the body, how precise we have to be. As much as engineering is my forte, I do want to still continue my studies in something that the world is currently moving towards to which is technology. Hence, I made a decision to continue on studies in Degree in Applied Artificial Intelligence.

title: About Me
text: After finishing my studies, I took a gap year to worked with Biosensors, a company specialised in building catheters as an Assistant Research and Design Engineer. I really enjoyed my time there where I get to witness the behind the scene of building something for the inert of body, how precise we had to be. As much as engineering is my forte, I do still want to continue my studies in something that the world is currently moving towards to which is technology. title: About Me
text:
As a curious individual, I am never afraid to try new things. A few years back, I was very involved with powerlifting where I get the satisfactory whenever I hit my personal best. In recent years, I have gotten really fond of rockclimbing as well as travelling. Good scenery and food always calms the soul.

Feel free to reach out to me via LinkedIn or drop me an E-mail at leenaswq@gmail.com

Thank you for taking the time to learn a bit about me!

title: About Me
text: I completed my O’Levels in 2018 and went on to Singapore Polytechnic to pursue a Diploma in Bioengineering. After finishing my studies, I took a gap year and worked with Biosensors, a company specialised in building catheters as an Research and Design Engineer. I really enjoyed my entire time there where I get to witness the behind the scene of the building something for inert of the body, how precise we have to be. As much as engineering is my forte, I do want to still continue my studies in something that the world is currently moving towards to which is technology. title: Hello I am Leena!

Education

title: Project
text:
1. Space Odyssey - Object-Oriented Programming

• Spent 3 months developing a functional end to end game engine and built an education game on top of the engine using Java
• Designed UML diagrams to model the engine’s structure
• Gained experience with game development concepts


2. Better Village - Web Systems and Technologies

• Developed a movie review website using PHP, HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and MySQL
• Implemented core features including user authentication using PHPMailer, password reset functionality, movie database, user review system
• Conducted accessibility testing using Axe DevTools
• Followed W3C standards for markup validation


3. Education Statistics - Data Visualisation


 • Developed an interactive data visualization project using R and various libraries including ggplot2, plotly, and tidyr
• Implemented data cleaning techniques including pivoting tables, handling missing values, and data type conversions
• Utilized ggplot2 and plotly to create visually appealing and informative charts with custom color palettes
• Demonstrated proficiency in R programming, data manipulation, and creating publication-ready visualizations

title: Interactive plots
text:
Remove unnecessary rows and columns


Code
df <- read_excel("Education Statistics Digest 2023-Statistical Tables.xlsx", sheet = "46", skip = 1, n_max = 5)


New names:
• `` -> `...2`


Code
df <- df[ , -2]

title: Interactive plots
section: Pitvot table and change Year datatype to Int
text:
Pitvot table and change Year datatype to Int


Code
# Convert to long format
df_long <- df |>
  pivot_longer(cols = -`Ethnic Group`, names_to = "Year", values_to = "Percentage")

# Ensure Year is integer
df_long$Year <- as.integer(df_long$Year)

title: Interactive plots
text:
Check for mising values


Code
sapply(df_long, function(x) sum(is.na(x)))

title: Interactive plots
text:
Colour Palette


Code
dark_color_palette <- c(
  "#009E73",  
  "#F5C710",  
  "#0072B2", 
  "#D55E00",  
  "#CC79A7"
)

title: Interactive plots
text:
Improvement 1


Code
# Create the plot
p <- ggplot(df_long, aes(x = Year, y = Percentage, color = `Ethnic Group`, group = `Ethnic Group`)) +
  geom_line() +
  geom_point() +
  labs(
    title = "Percentage of O-Level Students Who Progressed To Post-Secondary Education",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Percentage",
    color = "Ethnic Group") +
  scale_color_manual(values = dark_color_palette) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = unique(df_long$Year)) +
  theme_minimal()

# Convert to plotly object for interactivity
p_interactive <- ggplotly(p, tooltip = c("x", "y", "color"))

p_interactive <- p_interactive %>%
  layout(
    hoverlabel = list(
      font = list(
        size = 14,
        family = "Arial",
        color = "white"
      ),
      bordercolor = "black" 
    ),
    annotations = list(
      list(
        x = -0.05,
        y = -0.1,
        xref = 'paper',
        yref = 'paper',
        text = "Source: Ministry of Education Singapore",
        showarrow = FALSE,
        font = list(
          size = 12,
          family = "Arial",
          color = "black"
        ),
        align = "left"
      )
    )
  )

# Display the plot
p_interactive







Y-axis is scaled to be able to see differences more clearly
Interactive plot to hover over data point to see more information
legend outside the plot area to maximise the space for the data visualization
X-axis is labelled

title: Interactive plots
text:
Improvement 2


Code
# Create the main plot with Plotly
main_plot <- plot_ly(
  data = df_long,
  x = ~Year,
  y = ~Percentage,
  color = ~`Ethnic Group`,
  colors = dark_color_palette,
  type = 'scatter',
  mode = 'lines+markers',
  text = ~paste("Year:", Year, "<br>Percentage:", Percentage, "<br>Group:", `Ethnic Group`),
  hoverinfo = "text"
) %>% layout(
  yaxis = list(
    range = c(0, 100),
    tickvals = c(0, 25, 50, 75, 100),
    title = "Percentage"
  ),
  xaxis = list(
    tickvals = unique(df_long$Year),  # Set the tick values to unique years
    ticktext = as.character(unique(df_long$Year)),
    title = "Year"
  ),
  title = "Percentage of O-Level Students Who Progressed to Post-Secondary Education",
  legend = list(title = list(text = "Ethnic Group")),
  annotations = list(
    list(
      x = 0,
      y = -0.2,
      xref = 'paper',
      yref = 'paper',
      text = "Source: Ministry of Education Singapore",
      showarrow = FALSE,
      font = list(
        size = 12,
        family = "Arial",
        color = "black"
      ),
      align = "left"
    )
  ),
  margin = list(b = 100)  # Increase the bottom margin
)

# Add custom JavaScript for click zoom into point
main_plot <- main_plot %>%
  htmlwidgets::onRender("
    function(el, x) {
      el.on('plotly_click', function(d) {
        var point = d.points[0];
        if (point) {
          var yValue = point.y;
          var yBinRange = 30; // Define the bin range for y-axis
          var xBinRange = 1.5; // Define the bin range for x-axis to show 5 years
          var update = {
            'xaxis.range': [point.x - xBinRange, point.x + xBinRange], // Show 5 years around the clicked point
            'yaxis.range': [yValue - yBinRange, yValue + yBinRange]
          };
          Plotly.relayout(el, update);
        }
      });
    }
  ")

main_plot







Y-Axis starts from 0 to not mislead audience
Increase number of bins on Y-Axis for visibility
Interactive plot for visibility on click
legend outside the plot area to maximise the space for the data visualization
X-axis is labelled
